chapter: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 1: What is implied if a drug has more renal clearance than GFR?

options.a: Drug is reabsorbed by the renal tubules
options.b: Drug is secreted in the renal tubules
options.c: Drug is excreted in renal tubules
options.d: Drug is neither excreted nor reabsorbed in renal tubules

questions.explanation: If drug has more renal clearance than GFR, then drug is secreted in renal tubules. Excretion rate= (filtration rate- reabsorption rate)+ secretion rate. The clearance of the substance: • Equals the GFR if there is no net tubular secretion or reabsorption. • Exceeds the GFR if there is net tubular secretion. • Less than the GFR if there is net tubular reabsorption.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 2: Choose the correct formula regarding renal physiology.
questions.explanation:
The correct formula is Excretion rate = UV. • Filtration fraction = ( GFR / RPF ) * 100 = 20% (or ) 0.2 (approx) • Filtration rate = GFR * Plasma concentration • Clearance = U*V/P Where, 662 
Sold by @itachibot GFR = Glomerular filtration rate RPF = Renal plasma flow U = Concentration of the substance in urine V = Urine flow rate P = Concentration of the substance in plasma
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 3: Choose the correct option.

options.a: Inulin is completely secreted and never reabsorbed.
options.b: Glucose is completely reabsorbed in DCT.
options.d: PAH at any plasma concentration is completely filtered and secreted.

questions.explanation:
Creatinine is partially secreted and never reabsorbed. Clearance of creatinine (CCr) can also be 
used to determine GFR. Since creatinine is secreted by the tubules, the clearance of creatinine will 
be slightly higher than inulin. Hence, it overestimates GFR. Inulin is completely filtered and never reabsorbed. Hence, it can be used for GFR estimation. Glucose is completely reabsorbed below the renal threshold (i.e ~180mg/dl) in PCT. PAH(para amino hippuric acid) at low plasma concentrations is completely filtered and 
secreted. Hence, it can be used for estimation of renal blood flow.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 4: Renal plasma flow is being calculated using PAH in a patient. The technician inadvertently 
uses PAH thrice the recommended dose. What will be the estimated effective renal plasma 
flow?
questions.explanation:
Effective renal plasma flow in this patient will be falsely low. It is equal to the clearance of para-aminohippurate (PAH) as shown by the following equation. Where, • ERPF = Effective Renal Plasma Flow • UPAH = [PAH] in urine 663 
Sold by @itachibot • V= Urine flow rate • PPAH = [PAH] in plasma • CPAH = Clearance of PAH At high concentrations of PAH, as given in this question, tubular secretion attains saturation after 
which the clearance of PAH falls. Hence, a low ERPF will be seen.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following transporter is present in the ascending loop of Henle?
questions.explanation:
Thick ascending limb of loop of Henle has Na+ - 2Cl- - K+ co transporter that cotransports one 
Na+, one K+, and 2Cl– from the tubular lumen into the tubular cells. This is an example of 
secondary active transport. Na+ is transported out of the cell into the interstitium by Na, K ATPase in the basolateral 
membrane of the cell. Cl– exits in basolateral ClC–Kb Cl– channels. Barttin, a protein in the cell membrane, is essential 
for normal ClC–Kb function. K+ moves from the cell to the interstitium and the tubular lumen by ROMK(renal outer medullary 
potassium channel) and other K+ channels.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 6: The principal site of absorption of Na + is

options.c: Thick ascending limb of Loop of Henle

questions.explanation:
The principal site of absorption of Na + is PCT. About š0-š5% of filtered sodium is reabsorbed in 
the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), coupled with the movement of H+, glucose, amino acids, 
organic acids, phosphate, and other electrolytes and substances. All segments of nephron are involved in sodium reabsorption except thin descending loop of 
Henle. 664 
Sold by @itachibot % of filtered Na reabsorbed 
Part of nephron 
Main transporter involved š0 
PCT 
Na+–H+exchanger 30 
Thick ascending limb of the l 
oop of Henle Na+–2Cl-–K cotransporter 7 
DCT 
Na–Cl cotransporter 3 
Collecting ducts 
ENaC channels (regulated by 
aldosterone to permit homeo 
static adjustments)
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 7: Potassium is maximally absorbed in
questions.explanation:
Potassium is maximally absorbed in PCT. Potassium is freely filtered by the glomerulus. The bulk of filtered K+ is reabsorbed in the 
proximal tubule. In the proximal tubule, K+ absorption is primarily passive and proportional to 
Na+ and water through paracellular transport. K+ reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of Henle occurs through both transcellular (Na+- K+- 
2Cl- cotransport) and paracellular pathways. K+ secretion begins in the early distal convoluted tubule and progressively increases along the 
distal nephron into the cortical collecting duct . Most urinary K+ can be accounted for by K+ 
secretion mediated by principal cells. Under conditions of K+ depletion, reabsorption of K+ occurs 
in the collecting duct. It is the only electrolyte to be reabsorbed as well as secreted. 665 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 8: Bicarbonate is reabsorbed across the luminal membrane with the help of
questions.explanation:
Bicarbonate is reabsorbed at the luminal membrane in the form of CO2 and H2O with the help of 
Na+ - H+ exchanger. In the tubular cell of the PCT, CO2 and H2O recombine with the help of carbonic anhydrase II, 
and then dissociate into H+ and HCO3-. From here, the H+ moves back into the tubular lumen via 
the Na+ - H+ exchanger while the HCO3- is reabsorbed at the basolateral membrane via the Na+ - 
HCO3- co-transporter.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 9: True about renal tubular transport

options.c: H+ is absorbed in proximal tubule
options.d: Amino acid is reabsorbed in proximal tubule

questions.explanation:
666 
Sold by @itachibot Glucose and amino acids are completely reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. Option A: Maximum reabsorption occurs in proximal tubule Option B: Urea is reabsorbed and secreted. It is reabsorbed in PCT and in collecting duct. It is 
secreted in thin ascending loop of henle. Option C: H+ is secreted in PCT as well as in collecting ducts.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following occurs along with glucose transport into the cell?
questions.explanation:
Sodium symport occurs along with glucose transport into the cell. Sodium and glucose are co-transported across the luminal membrane of proximal tubular 
cells. This occurs via sodium glucose co-transporters (SGLT2 and SGLT1). The energy derived 
from the movement of Na+ is used to move glucose against its concentration gradient into the 
tubular cell. This is referred to as secondary active transport. The Na+ is then pumped out of the cell into the interstitium, and the glucose exits by facilitated 
diffusion via glucose transporter (GLUT)-2 along the basolateral membrane into the interstitial 
fluid. Clinical correlation: Fanconi-Bickel syndrome: Defective GLUT2 Isolated renal glycosuria: Defective SGLT2 667 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 11: Normal renal threshold (g/L) and transport maxima (mg/min) for glucose respectively are 
 
,
questions.explanation:
The actual renal threshold is about 200 mg/dL (i.e., 2 g/L ) (1g/L=100mg/dl) and the transport 
maximum for glucose is 375 mg/min. For substances that are actively reabsorbed or secreted, there is a limit to the rate at which 
the solute can be transported, which is referred to as the transport maximum. This limit is due to 
saturation of the specific transport systems involved. Normally, measurable glucose does not appear in the urine because essentially all the 
filtered glucose is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule. The transport maximum for glucose is about 375 mg/min, whereas the filtered load of glucose is 
only about 125 mg/min. With large increases in GFR and/or plasma glucose concentration 
that increase the filtered load of glucose above 375 mg/min, the excess glucose filtered is not 
reabsorbed and passes into the urine. When the plasma glucose concentration is 100 mg/100 ml and the filtered load is at its normal 
level (125 mg/min) there is no loss of glucose in the urine. However, when the plasma 
concentration of glucose rises above about 200 mg/100 ml, increasing the filtered load to about 
250 mg/min, a small amount of glucose begins to appear in the urine. This point is termed as the 
threshold for glucose. Splay is due to separation between filtered load and exceretion. It occurs due to different 
transport maximums of different nephrons. 668 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 12: The image of PAH excretion is depicted below. Match the labellings. 654 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: a. Filtered, b. Excreted, c. Tm, d. Secreted
options.b: a. Filtered, b. Secreted, c. Tm, d. Excreted
options.c: a. Secreted, b. Filtered, c. Tm, d. Excreted
options.d: a. Excreted, b. Filtered, c. Tm, d. Secreted

questions.explanation:
The labellings depticed are a. Filtered, b. Secreted, c. Tm, d. Excreted Filtered Load: The filtered load of PAH increases linearly as the unbound concentration of PAH 
increases (filtered load = GFR. [P]PAH). Secretion: At low concentrations of PAH, many carriers are available and secretion increases 
linearly as the plasma concentration increases. When the PAH concentration increases to a level 
where the carriers are saturated, Tm is reached. After this point, no matter how much the PAH 
concentration increases, there can be no further increase in the secretion rate. Excretion. For a secreted substance such as PAH, excretion is the sum of filtration and 
secretion. At low PAH concentrations (below Tm), excretion increases steeply with increases in 
plasma PAH concentration because both filtration and secretion are increasing. At PAH 
concentrations above Tm, excretion increases less steeply (and parallels the curve for filtration) 
because only the filtration component increases as concentration increases; secretion is already 
saturated.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 13: In a patient with uncontrolled diabetes, what is the value of plasma clearance of glucose?
questions.explanation:
In uncontrolled diabetes, the plasma clearance of glucose is greater than zero. Normally, all the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed and no glucose is excreted in the urine. 
Hence, the clearance is zero. In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma glucose concentration is 
greater than the renal threshold for reabsorption, excess glucose is excreted in the urine and the 
clearance is greater than zero. Clearance of different substances can be shown in a graph as follows: 669 
Sold by @itachibot The above graph depicts renal handling of glucose, inulin, and para-aminohippurate (PAH) and 
can be explained as follows: Glucose clearance: Normally, all the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed and no glucose is 
excreted in the urine. Hence, the clearance is zero. In uncontrolled diabetes, since the plasma 
glucose concentration is greater than the renal threshold for reabsorption, excess glucose is 
excreted in the urine and the clearance is greater than zero. Inulin clearance: Inulin is freely filtered and is neither reabsorbed nor secreted. Hence, it is 
constant and equal to the glomerular filtration rate. PAH clearance: PAH is both filtered and secreted. When plasma PAH is low, clearance is high. 
However, as plasma PAH rises above the threshold level for PAH secretion, clearance falls 
progressively.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient has a ■blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the 
amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below? 655 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min. Calculation: Step 1: Calculate total filtered glucose: In this question, • GFR = 90 ml/min • Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml). • Total filtered glucose = GFR X Plasma glucose concentration. = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml = 180 mg/min. Step 2: Check transport maximum: 670 
Sold by @itachibot In the above question transport maximum is 150 mg/min. Step 3: Calculate the excretion: Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum) = 180-150 mg/min = 30 mg/min
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 15: Choose the correct statement regarding the concentration of solutes at the end of proximal 
convoluted tubule

options.a: Concentration of glucose in tubular fluid is more than that of plasma
options.b: Concentration of urea in tubular fluid is more than that of plasma
options.c: Concentration of bicarbonate in tubular fluid is more than that of plasma
options.d: Concentration of sodium in tubular fluid is less than that of plasma

questions.explanation:
The concentration of urea in tubular fluid is more than that of plasma. [TF/P]>1, when solute is reabsorbed less quickly than water or when solute is secreted. Ex- 
PAH, Creatinine, Inulin, Urea. [TF/P]=1, when solute and water are reabsorbed at the same rate Ex - Na. [TF/P]<1, when solute is reabsorbed more quickly than water. Ex- glucose, amino acid, 
bicarbonate.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 16: The mechanism by which majority of water is reabsorbed in PCT is
questions.explanation:
Water reabsorption in PCT mainly occurs by osmosis. The proximal tubule reabsorbs š7% of the filtered water. The driving force for water reabsorption 
is a transtubular osmotic gradient established by reabsorption of solutes.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 17: A dehydrated patient is excreting hypertonic urine. Absorption of water in which part of the 
nephron causes this?
questions.explanation:
671 
Sold by @itachibot Hypertonic urine is excreted due to absorption of water in collecting duct. The final concentration of urine is determined by the amount of water reabsorption that occurs in 
the collecting ducts. The changes in osmolarity of the urine (hypo/hypertonic) depends on the 
amount of ADH (vasopressin) acting on the collecting ducts. The basic requirements for forming a concentrated urine (hypertonic urine) are • A high level of ADH, which increases the permeability of the distal tubules and collecting ducts 
to water, thereby allowing these tubular segments to avidly reabsorb water. • A high osmolarity of the renal medullary interstitial fluid, which provides the osmotic gradient 
necessary for water reabsorption to occur in the presence of high levels of ADH.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 18: A patient with diabetes insipidus is prescribed vasopressin. This drug has its maximum effect 
on which part of the renal tubule?
questions.explanation:
Vasopressin has the maximum effect on the collecting ducts. Vasopressin acts by inserting aquaporin 2 present in cytoplasmic vesicles of principal cells on to 
the apical membrane. The effect is mediated via the vasopressin V2 receptor, cyclic adenosine 
5-monophosphate (cAMP), and protein kinase A. When vasopressin is absent, the collecting duct 
epithelium is relatively impermeable to water.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is true about free water clearance?
questions.explanation:
Free water clearance is regulated by ADH. Free water clearance is defined as the amount of solute-free water generated by the kidneys, either 
when dilute urine or when concentrated urine is formed. Free-water clearance is positive, when excess water is being excreted (dilute urine). 672 
Sold by @itachibot Free-water clearance is negative, when excess solutes are being removed and water is being 
conserved (concentrated urine).
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 20: The following picture shows the composition of solute in the urine and plasma sample of 3 
patients. Identify the true statement. 657 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: A shows negative free water clearance, B is isotonic, C is positive free water clearance
options.b: A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C is positive free water clearance
options.c: A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C is negative free water clearance
options.d: A shows negative free water clearance B is isotonic C is negative free water clearance

questions.explanation:
Patient A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C shows negative free water clearance. Free water clearance is defined as the amount of solute-free water generated by the kidneys, either 
when dilute urine or when concentrated urine is formed. Patient A has positive free-water clearance, since excess water is being excreted (dilute urine). Patient C has negative free-water clearance, since excess solutes are being removed and water is 
being conserved (concentrated urine).
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 21: All are true except that  
.

options.b: Descending limb of loop of henle is permeable to water
options.c: Thick ascending limb is permeable to water
options.d: Distal tubule is permeable to water

questions.explanation: The ascending limb is always impermeable to H2O.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 22: The average urine osmolality in mosm/kg is  
.
questions.explanation: The average urine osmolality is 100-800 mosm/kg.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 23: What are the requirements for a patient to excrete concentrated urine?

options.a: High ADH levels and hypoosmolar renal medulla
options.b: Low ADH levels and hypoosmolar renal medulla
options.c: High ADH levels and hyperosmolar renal medulla
options.d: Low ADH levels and hyperosmolar renal medulla

questions.explanation:
The requirements for excreting concentrated urine are high ADH levels and hyperosmolar renal 
medulla. A high level of ADH, which increases the permeability of the distal tubules and collecting ducts to 
water, thereby allowing these tubular segments to avidly reabsorb water, and a high osmolarity of 
the renal medullary interstitial fluid, which provides the osmotic gradient necessary for water 
reabsorption to occur in the presence of high levels of ADH.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 24: Maximum osmotic gradient is found in
questions.explanation:
Maximum osmotic gradient is found in the inner medulla. The gradient of osmolarity from the 
cortex (300 mosm/L) to the inner medulla (1200 mosm/L) is produced by the loops of Henle as 
countercurrent multipliers and maintained by operation of the vasa recta as countercurrent 
exchangers. 673 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 25: Hyperosmolarity of renal medulla is due to
questions.explanation:
Hyperosmolarity of the medullary interstitium is mainly due to NaCl and urea. The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla 
are • Active transport of Na+ and co-transport of K+, Cl-, and other ions out of the thick portion of the 
ascending limb of the loop of Henle into the medullary interstitium. • Active transport of ions from the collecting ducts into the medullary interstitium. • Facilitated diffusion of urea from the inner medullary collecting ducts into the medullary 
interstitium. • Diffusion of only small amounts of water from the medullary tubules into the medullary 
interstitium
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism?

options.d: Descending limb of loop of Henle

questions.explanation:
Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) does not play a role in countercurrent mechanism. The countercurrent mechanism consists of 2 components: • Countercurrent multiplier: a. Absorption of water via Aquaporin 1 in thin descending limb b. Active transport of Na+- K+- 2Cl- in thick ascending limb c. Flow of fluid from PCT to DCT • Countercurrent exchanger: Vasa recta are involved in this process. They help in maintaining the 
osmotic gradient in the renal medulla. This is a passive process. 674 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 27: 659 
Sold by @itachibot Maximum osmolality that can be reached at the tip of medulla is proportional to

options.a: Distribution of Na-K-2Cl channel in the thick ascending loop of Henle
options.b: Permeability of descending loop to water

questions.explanation:
The maximum osmolality that can be reached at the tip of the medulla is proportional to the 
length of the loop of Henle, because the Loop of Henle acts as Countercurrent multiplier to 
maitain the gradient in medulla. Greater is the length of loop of Henle, greater will be the 
osmolality that can be reached at the tip of the medulla. In case of juxtamedullary nephrons with longer loops and thin ascending limbs, the osmotic 
gradient is spread over a greater distance and the osmolality at the tip of the loop is greater.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 28: Counter current blood flow is seen in all except
questions.explanation:
The eye does not have a countercurrent blood flow system. Heat and substances, including gases, steroids and peptide hormones, can pass from venous 
blood, interstitial fluid and lymph to the arterial blood; the process is called local counter-current 
transfer. Examples of countercurrent blood flow • Heat exchange between the arteries and venae comitantes of the limbs. • Vasa recta in the kidneys • Testes • Small intestine
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 29: All of the following are components responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the 
kidney except  
.

options.a: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
options.b: Water outflow in thin descending limb
options.c: Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
options.d: Flow of tubular fluid from PCT to DCT

questions.explanation:
675 
Sold by @itachibot Thin ascending limb is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism. The loop of Henle function as countercurrent multipliers and vasa recta as countercurrent 
exchangers. The functioning of the loop of Henle depends upon: • High permeability of the thin descending limb to water ( via aquaporin-1) • Active transport of Na+ and Cl- from the thick ascending limb • Inflow of tubular fluid from proximal tubule and outflow to the distal tubule. Note: The thin ascending limbs of juxtamedullary nephrons are permeable to Na+ and Cl- and 
hence do contribute passively to countercurrent multiplication. However, among the options 
provided, Option C is the best answer as the other options are directly responsible for the 
countercurrent mechanism.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 30: Which of the following is the diluting segment of the kidney?
questions.explanation:
The ascending thick limb of the loop of Henle is called the diluting segment. In the ascending limb, there is the movement of Na+ and Cl– out of the tubular lumen, and the 
tubular fluid becomes more dilute. When the fluid reaches the top of the ascending limb, it becomes hypotonic to plasma.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question:
Question 31: 660 
Sold by @itachibot As filtrate flows through PCT, the concentration of all of the following decreases except:
questions.explanation:
As the filtrate flows through the proximal convoluted tubule, the concentration of the chloride 
increases. • The concentration of chloride in the early part of the pCT is 105 mEq/L. • As the sodium is reabsorbed, it preferentially carries glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate. • This leaves behind the solute, that has a higher concentration of the chloride, which as it reaches 
the second half of the PCT is 140 mEq/L.
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an

questions.question: Question 32: Macula densa is formed by which part of the nephron?
questions.explanation:
Macula densa is formed by specialized tubular epithelial cells of the distal convoluted tubule. 676 
Sold by @itachibot The juxtaglomerular apparatus consists of the following parts: • Macula densa: At the end of the thick ascending limb of Henle, and at the beginning of the distal 
tubule, the tubular epithelial cells are specialized to form the macula densa. They detect sodium 
concentration of the fluid in the tubule (chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium, the 
macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to 
the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is 
increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased 
ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa 
cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, 
thereby decreasing the GFR. • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete 
renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in 
turn, increases blood pressure. 677 
Sold by @itachibot Acid-Base Balance, Renal Hormones and Micturition Reflex
questions.chapter_heading: Renal Tubular Functions  Urine Concentration an
